snippet: In the devastated Philippine town of Tacloban, aid is piling up with no way to deliver it, fuel is plentiful but merchants are too fearful to sell it, and disposal of the dead is halted by gunfire.
abstract: Typhoon gridlock threatens rescue operations in most devastated part of Philippines, with aid piling up but few ways to distribute it, plentiful gasoline but no merchants willing to sell it, and influx of emergency volunteers but no place to house them.

byline.original: By KEITH BRADSHER and RICK GLADSTONE
byline.contributor: Keith Bradsher reported from Tacloban, and Rick Gladstone from New York. Austin Ramzy contributed reporting from Cebu, the Philippines, and Gerry Mullany from Hong Kong.

lead_paragraph: In the devastated Philippine town of Tacloban, aid is piling up with no way to deliver it, fuel is plentiful but merchants are too fearful to sell it, and disposal of the dead is halted by gunfire.

headline.main: Logistical Hurdles Paralyze Relief Effort at the Center of a Typhoon’s Fury
headline.print_headline: Logistical Hurdles Paralyze Relief Effort at the Center of a Typhoon’s Fury
